Problem:
Consider the complex-valued function \\( z(t) = e^{iAt} \\) where \\( A \\) is a real constant and \\( i \\) represents the imaginary unit. The effect of the integral transformation \\( g(z) = \\int_{0}^{t} z(\\tau) d\\tau \\) is analyzed over time interval [0, T].

If a phase shift \\( \\alpha \\) is introduced to the function at \\( t = t_1 \\) so that the function becomes \\( z(t) = e^{iA(t-t_1) + \\alpha} \\) for \\( t > t_1 \\), will the final output of \\( g(z) \\) from t = 0 to T only depend on the original value of A?
Explanation: Introducing a phase shift modifies the phase part of the complex exponential in the function from the point of intervention, thereby affecting the outcome of the integral from t = t_1 to T. Therefore, both \\( A \\) and \\( \\alpha \\) influence the final result.
